title: 103_hr737
content: The Act titled "Strict Liability for Safer Streets Act of 1993" allows individuals harmed by handguns or assault weapons to sue manufacturers and importers for damages in federal court. Manufacturers and importers are held strictly liable for any bodily injury, death, or property damage caused by the discharge of these weapons. The "Strict Liability for Safer Streets Act of 1993" holds defendants strictly liable for damages resulting from the discharge of handguns or assault weapons, regardless of fault or defect. Defenses include no liability if the plaintiff was committing a felony or if the injury was self-inflicted. The "Strict Liability for Safer Streets Act of 1993" holds defendants strictly liable for damages resulting from the discharge of handguns or assault weapons. There is no liability if the injury was self-inflicted, caused by a law enforcement officer in the line of duty, or by a member of the United States armed forces. The "Strict Liability for Safer Streets Act of 1993" holds defendants strictly liable for damages resulting from the discharge of handguns or assault weapons. Liability is exempt if the injury was caused by a member of the Armed Forces or a security guard in the line of duty. The court may award a reasonable attorney's fee to the prevailing party in such cases. The "Strict Liability for Safer Streets Act of 1993" imposes a 2-year statute of limitations for bringing actions related to injuries caused by handguns or assault weapons. The Act applies only to firearms manufactured or imported after its effective date and does not limit other causes of action for bodily injury, death, or property damage resulting from firearm discharge. The term "handgun" refers to a firearm with a barrel less than 12 inches long, while an "assault weapon" is a firearm with a barrel of 12 inches or more that can use large capacity magazines and is not suitable for sporting purposes. A large capacity ammunition magazine is defined as a detachable device with a capacity of 15 or more rounds. A semiautomatic firearm is a repeating firearm that requires a separate trigger pull for each shot. A law enforcement officer is defined as an authorized officer, agent, or employee engaged in law enforcement activities. The terms "firearm", "importer", and "manufacturer" have specific meanings as defined in the United States Code. Title II of the Act requires the United States attorney to report to victims of federal crimes involving firearms within 30 days of a conviction. Title III includes a provision for an increase in tax on firearms. Title III of the Act proposes an increase in tax on firearms under Section 4181 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Act proposes a tax increase on firearms, shells, and cartridges sold by manufacturers, producers, or importers. The tax rates are 20% for firearms and 11% for shells and cartridges. The amendment will take effect after 30 days from the enactment date. Additionally, a floor stocks tax is imposed on firearms held for sale by dealers before the tax-increase date. The tax imposed on firearms before the tax-increase date is equal to the amount under section 4181 of the Code. Dealers holding firearms subject to the tax are liable for payment, to be made within 6 months of the tax-increase date as per regulations set by the Treasury Secretary. The tax-increase date is defined as the 1st day of the 1st calendar month starting more than 30 days after the enactment of the Act. The term "firearm" has the same meaning as in section 4181 of the Code. All laws and penalties applicable to taxes under section 4181 also apply to floor stocks taxes imposed by paragraph (1). SEC. 302 establishes the Hospital Gunshot Cost Relief Trust Fund under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Hospital Gunshot Cost Relief Trust Fund is created in the Treasury, funded by 50% of net revenues from firearms tax, with net revenues defined as the excess of firearms taxes over the decrease in tax imposed by chapter 1. The Hospital Gunshot Cost Relief Trust Fund is funded by firearms taxes and available for assisting urban hospitals in covering medical costs for gunshot victims without health insurance. The Hospital Gunshot Cost Relief Trust Fund, funded by firearms taxes, helps urban hospitals cover medical costs for uninsured gunshot victims.
